Good Find

I must say, Andy, good find on your part (his earlier writing). I hope and trust that you will try your best to get clear answers, from him, to explain his change of view.

He is not (as I hope you can see) providing clear answers so far. His use of words is broad and imprecise -- "fraud" and all that -- and he doesn't seem to be explaining, clearly and precisely, what it is in the scientific community's present understanding that he disagrees with, and why. What SCIENCE, specifically, does he disagree with, to what degree, and why? What evidence does he doubt, and what evidence does he have? And so forth.

Also, and perhaps here you are being polite with him, to get his views (a physicist) on humankind's adaptability and resilience? Really? If he would stick to matters of physics, and explain (using science) why his own mind has changed and what he disagrees with in the present scientific understanding, that would be great and sufficient. If he can't do that clearly, then how can we conclude that he's thinking clearly or even knows what he's talking about?

In any case, good find.

Jeff

What the early opinions of Lewis have in common with yours, Andy, and with Ropeik is that they were put out when relatively little measured data was available.

Then the main discussion is risk in general, psychological aspects, etc.

Think, say, the discussions about Martian fellows in the 1930's - what should we do to mitigate our risks if they come.

Since then much more data became available, not easily, not brought out for all to see, but nevertheless there: raw temperature measurements, satellite measurements of all kind of processes. This data grows by the day exponentially.

The data shows no particular measurable effects of the current rise in CO2 levels.

Think Martian fellows or the lack thereof after probe landings, about 1975.

Faced with this there were several reactions. People like Holdren (who still sends me, as a scientist, letters) or organizations like the APS decided to ignore the data and go for the "mitigation" money, whether in grants or for government revenue. Hansen decided to make up data in the unmeasured Arctic, as he declares openly.

That's the fraud part, when you ignore data for money. It will give you, Andy, as a reporter, plenty of material in the years to come.

That's the part that an honest scientist like Lewis just cannot stand. His exchange with you shows that he is as sharp as ever. His age makes him immune to the threat of cuts in support for his research.

Hal Lewis was in an ideal position to speak out, and he did it as eloquently as any. Let's hope he turns a tide, from fraud back to science...

Several commenters have defended Dr. Lewis by saying it is intellectually legitimate to change one's mind faced with new evidence. So it is, and he would not be a hypocrite were he claiming that scientists concerned about global warming are simply *wrong*. But he's making a much stronger accusation, that all scientists concerned enough about global warming to advocate policy change are committing fraud. So by his own logic, he himself once schemed and plotted to defraud others.

If he can't even concede it's possible to be wrong without being morally suspect, I don't think much of his scientific ethics.

Could people please replace "anthropogenic global warming" (AGW) with "fossil fueled-global warming" (FFGW), in the interests of scientific accuracy?

If fossil fuels had never been utilized, or if they were far more scarce than they've turned out to be, we can be pretty sure that atmospheric CO2 would now be down to around 280 ppm at best, and that the 20th century would have been a little cooler (or about the same) as the 19th century: can everyone agree on that?

Physically, the Earth's surface, oceans and atmosphere is what we call a steady-state dissipative system, primarily controlled by the flux of sunlight onto the globe. Due to the oceans, the planet's atmosphere is fairly moist in many places - and that also helps keep the surface warm, as anyone who has spent time in both deserts and coast regions can attest. At night, in a desert, the temperature plummets as energy escapes to space by radiation - but along coasts at night, the water vapor absorbs that energy, just as a blanket would - leading to warm air at night.

So, if you increase the level of atmospheric CO2, it begins to act the same way, but the effect is strongest at 10 km up - and this is clearly warming the planet at an appreciable rate, a process that will continue until about 50 years after fossil fuel combustion is eliminated globally, after which things will hopefully level off.

The effects are perhaps not immediately catastrophic, but you might want to check with the victims of Pakistani floods and Russian heat waves before making that assessment - and it will certainly make life more difficult and uncomfortable for literally billions of people, at the very least.

The truth is, if we had spent as much on renewable energy development in the past 40 years as we've spent on fossil fuel projects, we'd already have eliminated the use of the dirtier and more expensive fossil fuels (such as coal, tar sands, etc.) entirely, and be well on the way to phasing out natural gas and petroleum. CO2 levels might be a good 20 ppm lower than they are today
(we were at 340 ppm in 1980).

Interesting, isn't it, that the failure to take these steps may very well turn out to be one of the biggest blunders in human history?
